update.description:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new `static` mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new `<follow_model>` section must be added to `<world><gui><camera>` in sdformat (see related pull request [#238](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/238/new-section/diff) in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.
update.title: Static camera when following a model

content.html: Yup, this doesn't go into gazebo7 until we check ABI.

content.raw: @nkoenig , are we sure this won't break ABI? One public function is modified and a few public virtual functions are added in `redering/Camera`. I'm looking at [this](https://techbase.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B#The_Do.27s_and_Don.27ts) guide.
content.html: @nkoenig , are we sure this won't break ABI? One public function is modified and a few public virtual functions are added in redering/Camera. I'm looking at this guide.

Looks like the build isn't using the latest SDF:

```
#!c++


421: Warning [parser.cc:778] XML Element[static], child of element[track_visual] not defined in SDF. Ignoring[static]. You may have an incorrect SDF file, or an sdformat version that doesn't support this element.
421: Warning [parser.cc:778] XML Element[use_model_frame], child of element[track_visual] not defined in SDF. Ignoring[use_model_frame]. You may have an incorrect SDF file, or an sdformat version that doesn't support this element.
421: Warning [parser.cc:778] XML Element[xyz], child of element[track_visual] not defined in SDF. Ignoring[xyz]. You may have an incorrect SDF file, or an sdformat version that doesn't support this element.
421: Warning [parser.cc:778] XML Element[inherit_yaw], child of element[track_visual] not defined in SDF. Ignoring[inherit_yaw]. You may have an incorrect SDF file, or an sdformat version that doesn't support this element.
```

pull_request.title: Static camera when following a model

update.description:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new `static` mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new `<follow_model>` section must be added to `<world><gui><camera>` in sdformat (see related pull request [#238](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/238/new-section/diff) in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.
update.title: Static camera when following a model

content.raw: As I've recently learned, when we're creating a main window in a test, the last argument of Load can be false, because the main window creates the client scene.
